misconceptions.name: Solved a different problem (average acceleration instead of sum of even numbers)
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a program to compute average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of reading 5 integers and summing the even ones as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: I should write a program that reads v0, v1, and t and computes the average acceleration.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, use a loop and a conditional check to accumulate the sum of only the even numbers, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Prompt asks for 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 5 integers.
Only three inputs are read instead of five.
No loop or conditional logic related to even-number checking.
The final output reports 'The average acceleration' rather than the sum of even numbers.
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion between different textbook or assignment problems, leading to reusing an acceleration calculator solution for this question.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement carefully and rewrite the program to (1) read 5 integers, (2) loop over those values, (3) check each with n % 2 == 0, and (4) accumulate and print the sum of the even ones.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The entire structure, variable names, prompt text, and calculations all correspond to an average acceleration problem, with no elements related to summing even numbers.

evidence.note: The program reads three doubles labeled v0, v1, and t and computes average acceleration, with no code to read 5 integers, no loop, and no even-number filtering.

misconceptions.name: Solved Incorrect Problem
misconceptions.description: The student submitted code for an entirely different problem (calculating acceleration from v0, v1, and t) instead of the required task (calculating the sum of five even integers). The code is completely misaligned with the assignment instructions.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe this code calculates the required result for the assignment, or they submitted the wrong file entirely.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program must be structured to read five individual numerical inputs, use control flow (loops, conditionals) to identify and sum only the even numbers.
symptoms: Code calculates acceleration, not even sum
Asks for three double inputs (v0, v1, t) instead of five integers
No loops or conditional logic related to even number checking
misconceptions.root_cause: Submitting the wrong assignment file or a fundamental misunderstanding of the required task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the prompt for Q1. The goal is to sum even numbers, not calculate acceleration. Ensure you are submitting the correct file.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The class name, print statements, and calculations all point unambiguously to an acceleration calculation problem, which is not Q1.

evidence.note: Class name indicates the code is solving a problem related to acceleration, not summing even numbers.
The code prompts for 'v0, v1, and t' (3 doubles), not 5 integers, completely failing the input requirement.
The core calculation is for acceleration, which is irrelevant to finding the sum of even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Completely Wrong Problem Solution
misconceptions.description: Student has submitted code for a different problem entirely (acceleration calculator). The submission reads 3 floating-point values (v0, v1, t) and calculates acceleration, rather than reading 5 integers and summing even numbers as required.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe they are solving an acceleration calculation problem, not the sum of even numbers problem.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The task requires reading exactly 5 integers from the user, checking each for evenness (n % 2 == 0), accumulating the sum of only even numbers, and printing that sum.
symptoms: Program reads 3 double values instead of 5 integers
Program calculates acceleration instead of summing even numbers
Program prompts for v0, v1, and t instead of asking for 5 integers
Output shows 'The average acceleration is' instead of 'Sum of even numbers'
Contains debug print statements inappropriate for submission
misconceptions.root_cause: Student appears to have submitted code from a different assignment or mixed up which problem they were working on.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Rewrite the program to: (1) Create a loop that repeats 5 times, (2) Read an integer each iteration, (3) Check if (number % 2 == 0), (4) If true, add to a sum variable, (5) Print the final sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Near certainty because the code addresses a completely different problem with different inputs, different calculations, and different output format. This is not a misconception about the target problem but a fundamental misunderstanding of the assignment.

evidence.note: Program reads 3 doubles (v0, v1, t) instead of 5 integers. This is the wrong problem entirely.

evidence.snippet:
double acceleration = temp1 / t;
System.out.println("The average acceleration is " + acceleration);
evidence.note: Program calculates and outputs acceleration, not the sum of even numbers.
Multiple debug print statements indicate this code was not prepared for submission and belongs to a different problem.

misconceptions.name: Solving the wrong problem (average acceleration instead of sum of even integers)
misconceptions.description: The program computes average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of reading 5 integers and summing only the even ones, so it does not address the required problem at all.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes the task is to read v0, v1, and t as real numbers and compute the average acceleration using (v1 - v0) / t.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should read exactly 5 integers from the user, check each one to see if it is even (n % 2 == 0), accumulate the sum of the even numbers only, and then print that sum.
symptoms: Prompts the user for "v0, v1, and t" instead of 5 integers
Uses double variables v0, v1, and t instead of reading 5 integers
Computes acceleration = (v1 - v0) / t instead of any sum
Never checks whether a number is even or uses a loop to process 5 values
Output text refers to "average acceleration" instead of "Sum of even numbers"
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely confusion with a different assignment (average acceleration problem) or misreading of the current problem statement, leading to implementing an entirely different task.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Re-read the problem statement and redesign the program: use a loop to read 5 integers, use an if-statement with n % 2 == 0 to detect even numbers, accumulate their sum in a variable, and print the final sum with the required message.
related_concepts: Using loops to process a fixed number of inputs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Every part of the program (prompt, variable names, formula, and output) matches the classic average acceleration problem and none of it corresponds to summing even numbers from 5 integers.

evidence.note: All input, computation, and output logic is dedicated to calculating average acceleration from v0, v1, and t instead of reading 5 integers and summing the even ones.

misconceptions.name: Complete disregard for the problem statement
misconceptions.description: The student implemented a solution for calculating acceleration (a different problem entirely) instead of addressing the required task (summing 5 even numbers). This indicates a fundamental misunderstanding of which problem they were supposed to solve.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to have copied or written code for an entirely different assignment (calculating acceleration: a = (v1 - v0) / t) and submitted it for the 'Sum of Even Numbers' problem.

Logic does not involve loops or even number checks

misconceptions.remediation_hint: Please review the assignment instructions carefully and implement the code required for Q1: summing the even numbers out of five inputs.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code is unequivocally solving a different problem (acceleration calculation) from the one outlined in the prompt (sum of even numbers).

Input prompt asks for acceleration variables (v0, v1, t), not 5 general integers.
The core logic calculates acceleration using velocity subtraction and time division, contradicting the task of summing even numbers.

misconceptions.name: Incorrect data type and number of inputs
misconceptions.description: The student reads 3 inputs of type `double` using `input.nextDouble()` when the requirement was to read 5 inputs of type `integer`.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student believes that three floating-point inputs satisfy the requirement for five integer inputs, likely because they were solving a different problem involving doubles.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should use `input.nextInt()` five times to read the required number of inputs with the correct data type.
symptoms: Use of nextDouble()
Only 3 inputs are read
misconceptions.root_cause: The implementation is derived from an unrelated problem (acceleration calculation) which requires doubles.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Ensure you are using the correct data type method (`nextInt()`) and reading the correct number of values (5).
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code explicitly uses `nextDouble()` three times.

evidence.note: Reads only 3 inputs using nextDouble() (for doubles), instead of 5 inputs using nextInt() (for integers).

misconceptions.name: Using floating-point types for integer data
misconceptions.description: Student chose to read input as double values instead of integers, even though the problem explicitly specifies integers. This may indicate confusion about when to use different numeric data types.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that using double is acceptable for reading any numeric input, regardless of whether the problem specifies integers.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: Use int type when the problem specifies integers. Use double only when fractional values are explicitly needed. Different data types have different properties (precision, memory, operations).
symptoms: Input is read as double instead of int
Wrong data type for the problem context
misconceptions.root_cause: Possible confusion about the difference between integer and floating-point data types, or not carefully reading problem specifications.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Change Scanner methods from nextDouble() to nextInt(), and declare variables as int instead of double.
related_concepts: Precision and rounding in numeric types
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code uses double when int is specified in the problem. This is a type mismatch, though it may work due to implicit conversion.

evidence.note: Student reads input as double values using nextDouble(), not as integers using nextInt().

misconceptions.name: Not using loops for repetitive input processing
misconceptions.description: Student reads 3 individual inputs with sequential code instead of using a loop structure. For 5 inputs, this violates the requirement and suggests a misconception about when and how to use loops.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that reading multiple inputs requires writing separate lines of code for each input, without recognizing the need for a loop.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: When processing multiple inputs of the same type, use a loop (for or while) to reduce code duplication and handle any number of inputs efficiently. A for loop with 5 iterations would read 5 integers in a clean, scalable way.
symptoms: No loop structure in the code
Only 3 values processed instead of 5
Repetitive code pattern (read, print debug) is not factored into a loop
misconceptions.root_cause: Student may not understand the purpose of loops or when they are necessary. May be unfamiliar with counter-controlled loops (for loops).
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Use a for loop: `for(int i = 0; i < 5; i++) { int num = input.nextInt(); ... }` to read 5 integers efficiently.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The problem explicitly requires reading 5 inputs, but code only reads 3 without any loop. This is a clear deviation from requirements.

evidence.note: Sequential input reading without loop; only 3 inputs instead of 5 required.

misconceptions.name: Missing filtering logic for even numbers
misconceptions.description: Student does not implement any conditional logic to check if numbers are even. The modulus operator (%) is never used, and there is no if statement to filter the numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to believe that the program should perform a calculation on all inputs (acceleration) rather than filter inputs based on a condition.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To solve this problem, you must check each number using the modulus operator (n % 2 == 0) inside an if statement. Only numbers where n % 2 == 0 (even numbers) should contribute to the sum. This requires combining iteration, conditionals, and accumulation.
symptoms: No if statement checking for even numbers
Modulus operator (%) not used in the code
No filtering logic at all
misconceptions.root_cause: Student appears to be solving a completely different problem (acceleration calculation) and may not have understood the problem requirements to filter even numbers.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Add a conditional: `if (num % 2 == 0) { sum += num; }` inside the loop to only add even numbers to the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The problem explicitly requires filtering for even numbers using n % 2 == 0 logic. This is completely absent from the code.

evidence.note: Code performs arithmetic instead of checking if numbers are even. No conditional logic for filtering appears anywhere.
